(CBS) QUOTE OF THE DAY
“The only way to make a man trustworthy is to trust him.” - 
      Henry Stimson 

TODAY’S TRIVIA The longest name in the Bible is 
      Mahershalalhashbaz (Isaiah 8:1). 

TONIGHT ON THE CBS 
      EVENING NEWS Here's an early look 
      at what we are working on from Anchor and Managing Editor, Katie Couric 
      Hi everyone, The scourge of terrorism got worse last 
      year. A new report says attacks worldwide jumped 25 percent — and that's 
      not all. David Martin at the Pentagon will have the latest on what 
      the report means for the war on terror. A victory in that war was 
      won in Britain today. Five defendants were found guilty of plotting a 
      massive terrorist attack. They were discovered during one of the country’s 
      most intensive surveillance operations ever. Sheila MacVicar will 
      have the latest. A woman known as the D.C. Madam has everyone 
      talking inside the Beltway and beyond. She says she's not naming names — 
      exactly. Instead, she has handed over her phone records, which reportedly 
      list prominent individuals — among them executives, the head of a 
      conservative think-tank and an administration economist — as clients. 
      Bob Orr will have the story. Venezuelan president Hugo 
      Chavez claimed today that Cuban president Fidel Castro is back "in charge" 
      after being out of the public eye for more than nine months while 
      recovering from intestinal surgery. But is the 80-year-old Castro well 
      enough to lead? Lara Logan, our chief foreign correspondent, will 
      report from Cuba. We will also take you to Shandong Province, 
      China, known as the world’s salad bowl — it exports more produce than 
      anywhere else on the planet. It's an open secret that manufacturers there 
      add melamine to pet food to boost apparent protein content — a fact that 
      has brought the entire region under intense international scrutiny. Can 
      Shandong convince the world its products are safe to eat? Barry 
      Petersen will report. Had you heard of melamine before it 
      tainted pet food? The chemical can to be used to coat tabletops, fertilize 
      crops and even masquerades as a protein. Nancy Cordes will have 
      more. Cigarettes and drugs can be addictive, but what about your 
      PC? Daniel Sieberg will begin our series "Caught in the Web" with 
      the story of a family torn apart by computer-game addiction. 
      Finally, our chief White House correspondent Jim Axelrod 
      will report on White House press secretary Tony Snow’s return to work five 
      weeks after doctors discovered a recurrence of his cancer. Snow said he 
      feels "unbelievably lucky and unbelievably blessed." I hope you’ll 
      join us. Katie For more on two of the stories noted 
      above, please click on the following links: D.C. Madam 
      "Sorry" For Outing Client Click Here Pet Food Toxin Said 
      To Be Common In China Click Here Here's an early look 
      at one of the stories we are working on for tomorrow's broadcast... A 
      STAGGERING number of people are addicted to Internet pornography. Part 2 
      of our series, "caught in the web" shows you where MANY are going for 
      help. That story and more, Tuesday night on THE CBS EVENING NEWS. 
      If you would like more information on any of these stories or the 
      broadcast, please click on the following address and e-mail us: 
      evening@cbsnews.com 

TONIGHT ON DAVID LETTERMAN Dave sits down with 
      actress Kirsten Dunst AND impressionist Rob Magnotti… Plus, musical guests 
      Dinosaur Jr! 

TUESDAY MORNING ON THE EARLY SHOW Harry Smith, 
      Hannah Storm, and Russ Mitchell anchor THE EARLY 
      SHOW from New York. Dave Price will 
      bring us the weather. Julie Chen is off. Along with the 
      top news of the day, we will also have the following stories:
GEORGE TENET AT THE CENTER OF THE STORM: In his new book, 
      At the Center of the Storm, former CIA director George Tenet 
      reveals his feelings behind the way the Bush administration handled the 
      war in Iraq. He says that he and other CIA officials were “betrayed”. In 
      an exclusive interview on 60 MINUTES 
      this Sunday, Tenet told Scott Pelley that the White House misused 
      the phrase “slam dunk,” attributing those two words as justification to go 
      to war. Tuesday morning, Tenet will join us with more on his book and how 
      he feels now about the Bush administration. CSI MIAMI BEHIND 
      THE SCENES: On Monday night's CSI:Miami, one of the Crime Scene 
      Investigators is forced to face his vices, with some alarming 
      repercussion. Two of the stars of the hit show, David Caruso and Jonathan 
      Togo, will tell us about the consequences of Ryan's actions. EARLY 
      SHOW National Correspondent Tracy Smith 
      will have all the details. DAVE RAMSEY VIEWER LETTERS: YOUR 
      FINANCIAL QUESTIONS ANSWERED: When it comes to personal finances, a 
      lot of people have a lot of questions. How can you pay off your credit car 
      debt? What about investing your pension to maximize your money? And, how 
      can stay-at-home parents achieve financial freedom – is it feasible? We 
      decided to call on our financial guru Dave Ramsey to answer a 
      handful of those questions Tuesday morning. ALEX’S LEMONADE 
      STAND: You may remember the story of Alexandra Scott: the brave little 
      girl from Pennsylvania who decided to fight childhood cancer by selling 
      lemonade. It's been seven years since Alex set up her first stand...and 
      almost three years since she lost her own battle with cancer. But the 
      movement Alex Scott started continues to grow. EARLY 
      SHOW National Correspondent Tracy Smith 
      has her story and Alex’s parents Liz and Jay, and her brothers Patrick, 
      Eddie and Joey, will join us Tuesday morning to give us an update on the 
      amazing work they are continuing to do in Alex's honor. CHUCK 
      BARRIS ON THE BIG QUESTION: In his new novel, game show host turned 
      writer Chuck Barris paints a vivid portrait of a daring new game show. In 
      The Big Question, the plot revolves around an idea for a new 
      reality show, in which contestants have the chance to win $100 million 
      dollars or be executed on live television. Sound over the top? The book’s 
      central character doesn’t think so. And, not surprisingly, the premise of 
      the show within the book is not the most shocking aspect of the story, but 
      rather what gives shock value are the lives of three potential contestants 
      who all eager to change their fates. If you would like more 
      information on any of these stories or the broadcast, please click on the 
      following address and e-mail us: earlyshow@cbs.com
